elements.content: Three novel isostructural lanthanide organic frameworks, |(H2O)(H3O)|[Ln(HPyImDC)(OX)0.5Cl] (Ln = Pr (1), Nd (2), and Sm (3), H3PyImDC = 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid, H2OX = oxalic acid) have been prepared under hydrothermal conditions and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, elemental analysis, IR spectra, and thermogravimetric analysis. The results of crystal structural analysis indicate that three compounds are isomorphous 3D frameworks, which are constructed by lanthanide polyhedral {LnNClO6}, 4-connected HPyImDC2– ligand and bridging OX2– ligand. The HPyImDC2– ligand offering its four oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom of the pyridyl group, and the OX2– ligand offering all its four oxygen atoms coordinate with the lanthanide ions, which is a key essential for constructing the 3D frameworks. Topological analysis reveals that the 3D framework can be simplified into a 5-connected network with the lanthanide ion as a unique node, possessing the rare sqp topology. Meanwhile, the luminescent properties of three compounds in the solid state at room temperature are also investigated.
elements.clean_text: Three novel isostructural lanthanide organic frameworks, |(H2O)(H3O)|[Ln(HPyImDC)(OX)0.5Cl] (Ln = Pr (1), Nd (2), and Sm (3), H3PyImDC = 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid, H2OX = oxalic acid) have been prepared under hydrothermal conditions and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, elemental analysis, IR spectra, and thermogravimetric analysis. The results of crystal structural analysis indicate that three compounds are isomorphous 3D frameworks, which are constructed by lanthanide polyhedral {LnNClO6}, 4-connected HPyImDC2- ligand and bridging OX2- ligand. The HPyImDC2- ligand offering its four oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom of the pyridyl group, and the OX2- ligand offering all its four oxygen atoms coordinate with the lanthanide ions, which is a key essential for constructing the 3D frameworks. Topological analysis reveals that the 3D framework can be simplified into a 5-connected network with the lanthanide ion as a unique node, possessing the rare sqp topology. Meanwhile, the luminescent properties of three compounds in the solid state at room temperature are also investigated.

elements.content: H3PyImDC and oxalate, with selective nitrogen−oxygen chelating, directionality and substrate-binding ability, served as 4-connected linker and bridging linker, respectively, chelating with lanthanide ions (Ln = Pr, Nd and Sm) to construct three isostructural lanthanide−organic frameworks with 5-connected sqp network.
elements.clean_text: H3PyImDC and oxalate, with selective nitrogen-oxygen chelating, directionality and substrate-binding ability, served as 4-connected linker and bridging linker, respectively, chelating with lanthanide ions (Ln = Pr, Nd and Sm) to construct three isostructural lanthanide-organic frameworks with 5-connected sqp network.

elements.content: Recently, the design and synthesis metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with mixed organic ligand are of great interest in view of not only their intriguing architectures but also for their potential applications in gas storage, carbon dioxide capture, and renewable catalysts. It is well-known that the considerable change in the coordination mode of organic ligand may differ in structures, therefore, mixed organic ligand has been proven to be effective and useful in the construction of MOFs. 4,5-Imidazoledicarboxylic acid (H3ImDC), as a rigid and directional bridging ligand, has become a kind candidate for the construction of metal–organic materials, especially for zeolite-like metal–organic frameworks (ZMOFs). Among the reported networks is the functionalized H3ImDC, which remains largely unexplored. It is evident that functionalized H3ImDC ligand, at the 2-positon of the imidazole ring, with diverse substituent groups such as methyl, ethyl, or pyridyl, which will permit the construction of its derivative, have become a class of superior ligand for constructing MOFs with structural diversity in architectures and topologies as well. Furthermore, the different substitute groups can rotate freely and produce some spatial effect on the adjacent carboxylic groups, which give rise to their different coordination modes. Taking the above into account, 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (H3PyImDC) will be an ideal ligand and the N-donor of the pyridyl groups can take part in coordination with metal centers. Then, oxalate acid (H2OX) as a rigid planar ligand with multiple coordination sites will be a good second organic ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recently, the design and synthesis metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with mixed organic ligand are of great interest in view of not only their intriguing architectures but also for their potential applications in gas storage, carbon dioxide capture, and renewable catalysts. It is well-known that the considerable change in the coordination mode of organic ligand may differ in structures, therefore, mixed organic ligand has been proven to be effective and useful in the construction of MOFs. 4,5-Imidazoledicarboxylic acid (H3ImDC), as a rigid and directional bridging ligand, has become a kind candidate for the construction of metal-organic materials, especially for zeolite-like metal-organic frameworks (ZMOFs). Among the reported networks is the functionalized H3ImDC, which remains largely unexplored. It is evident that functionalized H3ImDC ligand, at the 2-positon of the imidazole ring, with diverse substituent groups such as methyl, ethyl, or pyridyl, which will permit the construction of its derivative, have become a class of superior ligand for constructing MOFs with structural diversity in architectures and topologies as well. Furthermore, the different substitute groups can rotate freely and produce some spatial effect on the adjacent carboxylic groups, which give rise to their different coordination modes. Taking the above into account, 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (H3PyImDC) will be an ideal ligand and the N-donor of the pyridyl groups can take part in coordination with metal centers. Then, oxalate acid (H2OX) as a rigid planar ligand with multiple coordination sites will be a good second organic ligand.

elements.content: Considering these in mind, our group has effectively employed H3ImDC derivatives to construct a series of novel architectures including a 3D (4,4)-connected pts net from 2-EtImDC, a (3,5)-connected net from 2-MeIMDC, two novel chiral frameworks with bmn and lcy-a nets, a (3,6)-connected net with ant net, and a 4,4-connected bbm net from H3PyImDC. It is worth mentioning that, in above compounds, 2-EtImDC, 2-MeIMDC, and H3PyImDC present distinct coordination modes than the parent H3ImDC ligand.
elements.clean_text: Considering these in mind, our group has effectively employed H3ImDC derivatives to construct a series of novel architectures including a 3D (4,4)-connected pts net from 2-EtImDC, a (3,5)-connected net from 2-MeIMDC, two novel chiral frameworks with bmn and lcy-a nets, a (3,6)-connected net with ant net, and a 4,4-connected bbm net from H3PyImDC. It is worth mentioning that, in above compounds, 2-EtImDC, 2-MeIMDC, and H3PyImDC present distinct coordination modes than the parent H3ImDC ligand.

elements.content: On the basis of current research on MOFs based on H3ImDC derivatives, we have explored H3PyImDC and H2OX as a mixed ligand to react with lanthanide nitrate. As expected, an intriguing structural change was observed that the H3PyImDC and H2OX ligand successfully cooperate with the lanthanide ions and present variety of coordination modes in the three novel 3D lanthanide-organic frameworks, |(H2O)(H3O)|[Ln(HPyImDC)(OX)0.5Cl] (Ln = Pr (1), Nd (2), and Sm (3)). Obviously, this is a continuing study of the coordination of H3ImDC derivatives as well as H2OX as the second ligand. The as-synthesized samples were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies, elemental analysis, and infrared spectra. Their thermal stability and photoluminescent properties were also evaluated.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of current research on MOFs based on H3ImDC derivatives, we have explored H3PyImDC and H2OX as a mixed ligand to react with lanthanide nitrate. As expected, an intriguing structural change was observed that the H3PyImDC and H2OX ligand successfully cooperate with the lanthanide ions and present variety of coordination modes in the three novel 3D lanthanide-organic frameworks, |(H2O)(H3O)|[Ln(HPyImDC)(OX)0.5Cl] (Ln = Pr (1), Nd (2), and Sm (3)). Obviously, this is a continuing study of the coordination of H3ImDC derivatives as well as H2OX as the second ligand. The as-synthesized samples were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies, elemental analysis, and infrared spectra. Their thermal stability and photoluminescent properties were also evaluated.

elements.content: The 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (H3PyImDC) were prepared according to reported procedures. All other reagents were used as received from commercial sources without further purification. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a Rigaku 2550 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Elemental analysis was performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 element analyzer. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analyses were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer Optima 3300Dv spectrometer. Infrared spectra were recorded within the 400–4000 cm–1 region on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer using KBr pellets. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TG) was performed on a NETZSCH STA 449C analyzer in air with heating rates of 10 °C·min–1. Fluorescence spectra were collected on a Shimadzu RF-5301 PC spectrophotometer at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

The 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (H3PyImDC) were prepared according to reported procedures. All other reagents were used as received from commercial sources without further purification. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a Rigaku 2550 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Elemental analysis was performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 element analyzer. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analyses were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer Optima 3300Dv spectrometer. Infrared spectra were recorded within the 400-4000 cm-1 region on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer using KBr pellets. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TG) was performed on a NETZSCH STA 449C analyzer in air with heating rates of 10 °C⋅min-1. Fluorescence spectra were collected on a Shimadzu RF-5301 PC spectrophotometer at room temperature.

elements.content: A mixture of Ln(NO3)3·6H2O (Ln = Pr, Nd and Sm, 0.5 mmol), H3PyImDC (0.5 mmol), oxalic ligand (0.25 mmol), HCl (0.25 mmol), and 6 mL of H2O was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated at 140 °C for 96 h. Block crystals were collected (50–60% yield based on Ln(NO3)3·6H2O). The phase purity was confirmed by the evident similarities between the simulated and the experimental XRD patterns as seen in . Elemental analysis (wt %) for 1: calcd C 27.04, H 2.06, N 8.60, Pr 28.84; found C 27.22, H 1.98, N 8.64, Pr 28.87. Elemental analysis (wt %) for 2: calcd C 26.86, H 2.05, N 8.54, Nd 29.32; found C 26.96, H 2.02, N 8.62, Nd 29.28. Elemental analysis (wt %) for 3: calcd C 26.53, H 2.02, N 8.44, Sm 30.19; found C 26.52, H 1.95, N 8.64, Nd 30.18. IR (KBr, cm–1) for three compounds as shown in . For 1: 3426 (m), 3146 (m), 1666 (vs), 1528 (vs), 1399 (s), 1126 (w), 790 (vs), 636 (m). For 2: 3426 (m), 3160 (m), 1666 (vs), 1526 (vs), 1391 (s), 1124 (w), 799 (vs), 636 (w). For 3: 3426 (m), 3142 (m), 1660 (vs), 1520 (vs), 1400 (s), 1120 (w), 792 (vs), 630 (w).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Compounds 1-3 

A mixture of Ln(NO3)3⋅6H2O (Ln = Pr, Nd and Sm, 0.5 mmol), H3PyImDC (0.5 mmol), oxalic ligand (0.25 mmol), HCl (0.25 mmol), and 6 mL of H2O was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated at 140 °C for 96 h. Block crystals were collected (50-60% yield based on Ln(NO3)3⋅6H2O). The phase purity was confirmed by the evident similarities between the simulated and the experimental XRD patterns as seen in . Elemental analysis (wt %) for 1: calcd C 27.04, H 2.06, N 8.60, Pr 28.84; found C 27.22, H 1.98, N 8.64, Pr 28.87. Elemental analysis (wt %) for 2: calcd C 26.86, H 2.05, N 8.54, Nd 29.32; found C 26.96, H 2.02, N 8.62, Nd 29.28. Elemental analysis (wt %) for 3: calcd C 26.53, H 2.02, N 8.44, Sm 30.19; found C 26.52, H 1.95, N 8.64, Nd 30.18. IR (KBr, cm-1) for three compounds as shown in . For 1: 3426 (m), 3146 (m), 1666 (vs), 1528 (vs), 1399 (s), 1126 (w), 790 (vs), 636 (m). For 2: 3426 (m), 3160 (m), 1666 (vs), 1526 (vs), 1391 (s), 1124 (w), 799 (vs), 636 (w). For 3: 3426 (m), 3142 (m), 1660 (vs), 1520 (vs), 1400 (s), 1120 (w), 792 (vs), 630 (w).

elements.content: Suitable single crystals of 1–3 were selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The intensity data was collected on a Rigaku RAXIS RAPID diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The numbers of collected reflections and independent reflections were 7571 and 2436 for 1, 17002 and 3742 for 2, and 12537 and 3061 for 3. Absorption corrections were applied by using SADABS. The structures were solved with direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2 using the SHELXTL program package. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic temperature parameters. The hydrogen atoms of the organic ligand and water molecules were assigned with common isotropic displacement factors or by geometrical restrains. It is noted that the Cl atoms were disordered over two positions with occupancy factors 0.75 and 0.25 in three compounds, respectively. Crystallographic data for 1–3 (CCDC 848730–848732) have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. Data can be obtained free of charge upon request at www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Crystal data and detailed data collection and refinement are summarized in Table . Topology information was obtained using TOPOS 4.0 program, and the detailed topological information can be seen in .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structure Determination and Structure Refinement

Suitable single crystals of 1-3 were selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The intensity data was collected on a Rigaku RAXIS RAPID diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The numbers of collected reflections and independent reflections were 7571 and 2436 for 1, 17002 and 3742 for 2, and 12537 and 3061 for 3. Absorption corrections were applied by using SADABS. The structures were solved with direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2 using the SHELXTL program package. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic temperature parameters. The hydrogen atoms of the organic ligand and water molecules were assigned with common isotropic displacement factors or by geometrical restrains. It is noted that the Cl atoms were disordered over two positions with occupancy factors 0.75 and 0.25 in three compounds, respectively. Crystallographic data for 1-3 (CCDC 848730-848732) have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. Data can be obtained free of charge upon request at www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Crystal data and detailed data collection and refinement are summarized in Table . Topology information was obtained using TOPOS 4.0 program, and the detailed topological information can be seen in .

R 1 = ∑∥F o| – |F c ∥/∑|F o |. wR 2 = [∑[w(F o 2 – F c 2)2]/∑[w(F o 2)2]]1/2.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compounds 1–3 are isostructural and all crystallize in monoclinic system space group C2/c, and thus only the structure of compound 1 is described in detail. As shown in , each asymmetric unit contains one crystallographically unique Pr3+ ion, one HPyImDC2– ligand, half an OX2– ligand, one coordinated Cl– anion, and two guest water molecules. The Pr3+ ion assumes an icosahedral geometry {PrNClO6} in which the Pr3+ ion is coordinated by one nitrogen, one Cl– anion, and six oxygen atoms. One nitrogen atom (N1) is from the pyridyl group, and four oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O4, and O5) are from carboxylic groups, and the other two oxygen atoms (O3 and O6) are from the oxalic ligand, respectively. The Pr–O distances are in the range of 2.393(4)–2.619(3) Å, the Pr–N distance is 2.742(4) Å, and the average distance Pr–Cl bond is 2.235(4) Å, which are all in agreement with those observed for the eight-coordinated Pr3+ ions. The detailed bond lengths and angles are shown in (containing compounds 2 and 3). Each of the divalent HPyImDC2– anion chelates with four Pr3+ ions to serve as a 4-connected linker (see Figure a), and the oxalic acid acts as a bridging linker with four of its oxygen atoms connecting with two Pr3+ ions. Therefore, each of the Pr3+ ions as a metal center connects to five other Pr3+ ions via the 4-connected HPyImDC2– and bridging OX2– ligand. Six of Pr3+ ions with four HPyImDC2– ligands and one OX2– ligand form a 5-connected square-pyramidal building unit. One Pr3+ ions occupied the center of the square-pyramidal and other four Pr3+ ions located at the vertex of square-pyramidal as seen in Figure a. Consequently, the 5-connected square-pyramidal units connect with each other via vertex sharing to give rise to a 3D open framework with uncoordinated water molecules reside in the open channels (Figure b). Interestingly, the 3D framework contains two distinct channels: one is an elongated channel along the [010] direction as shown in Figure b, approximately 3 Å × 9.5 Å in diameter, and the other one is the square channel along the [100] direction, approximately 3.5 Å × 4 Å in diameter (see Figure c). Calculation performed using MS Modeling 4.0 reveals that the total solvent-accessible volume is equal to 410.57 Å3 per unit cell, which accounts for 14.9% of the cell volume.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compounds 1-3 are isostructural and all crystallize in monoclinic system space group C2/c, and thus only the structure of compound 1 is described in detail. As shown in , each asymmetric unit contains one crystallographically unique Pr3+ ion, one HPyImDC2- ligand, half an OX2- ligand, one coordinated Cl- anion, and two guest water molecules. The Pr3+ ion assumes an icosahedral geometry {PrNClO6} in which the Pr3+ ion is coordinated by one nitrogen, one Cl- anion, and six oxygen atoms. One nitrogen atom (N1) is from the pyridyl group, and four oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O4, and O5) are from carboxylic groups, and the other two oxygen atoms (O3 and O6) are from the oxalic ligand, respectively. The Pr-O distances are in the range of 2.393(4)-2.619(3) Å, the Pr-N distance is 2.742(4) Å, and the average distance Pr-Cl bond is 2.235(4) Å, which are all in agreement with those observed for the eight-coordinated Pr3+ ions. The detailed bond lengths and angles are shown in  (containing compounds 2 and 3). Each of the divalent HPyImDC2- anion chelates with four Pr3+ ions to serve as a 4-connected linker (see Figure a), and the oxalic acid acts as a bridging linker with four of its oxygen atoms connecting with two Pr3+ ions. Therefore, each of the Pr3+ ions as a metal center connects to five other Pr3+ ions via the 4-connected HPyImDC2- and bridging OX2- ligand. Six of Pr3+ ions with four HPyImDC2- ligands and one OX2- ligand form a 5-connected square-pyramidal building unit. One Pr3+ ions occupied the center of the square-pyramidal and other four Pr3+ ions located at the vertex of square-pyramidal as seen in Figure a. Consequently, the 5-connected square-pyramidal units connect with each other via vertex sharing to give rise to a 3D open framework with uncoordinated water molecules reside in the open channels (Figure b). Interestingly, the 3D framework contains two distinct channels: one is an elongated channel along the [010] direction as shown in Figure b, approximately 3 Å × 9.5 Å in diameter, and the other one is the square channel along the [100] direction, approximately 3.5 Å × 4 Å in diameter (see Figure c). Calculation performed using MS Modeling 4.0 reveals that the total solvent-accessible volume is equal to 410.57 Å3 per unit cell, which accounts for 14.9% of the cell volume.

elements.content: A description of the structure of compounds 1–3. (a) Illustration of the Pr3+ ions, viewed as a 5-connected square-pyramidal building units. (b) Representation of the 3D framework with the elongated channels along [001] direction. (c) Stick view of channels along [010] direction. (d) Polyhedral view of the sqp network. (e) Topological features displayed by (e) tiling style and (f) face symbol for the three-periodic sqp net. Color scheme: carbon = gray, nitrogen = blue, oxygen = red, lanthanide = green.

(b) Representation of the 3D framework with the elongated channels along [001] direction. (c) Stick view of channels along [010] direction. (d) Polyhedral view of the sqp network. (e) Topological features displayed by (e) tiling style and (f) face symbol for the three-periodic sqp net. Color scheme: carbon = gray, nitrogen = blue, oxygen = red, lanthanide = green.

elements.content: Topologically, the 5-connected square-pyramidal building units can be simplified into 5-connected node with the Pr3+ ions as metal center, so the resulting structure can be regarded as a 5-connected sqp network as shown in Figure d,e. There is one T site and two unique tiles [64] + [42.62] in the sqp network (Figure f). To the best of our knowledge, only few MOFs with sqp network have been reported referenced to the Reticular Chemistry Structure Resource (RSCR) database, and compound 1 is the first reported MOFs with sqp networks constructed by mixed organic ligands.
elements.clean_text: Topologically, the 5-connected square-pyramidal building units can be simplified into 5-connected node with the Pr3+ ions as metal center, so the resulting structure can be regarded as a 5-connected sqp network as shown in Figure d,e. There is one T site and two unique tiles [64] + [42.62] in the sqp network (Figure f). To the best of our knowledge, only few MOFs with sqp network have been reported referenced to the Reticular Chemistry Structure Resource (RSCR) database, and compound 1 is the first reported MOFs with sqp networks constructed by mixed organic ligands.

elements.content: To date, H3PyImDC has presented five types of coordination modes as terminal-, linear-, or T-shaped linkers in the reported structures (see ), while in our structures, H3PyImDC serves as a 4-connected linker with four oxygen and one pyridyl nitrogen atoms participating in coordination with lanthanide ions (). Compared with MOFs constructed by 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid and oxalic acid mixed ligands, the combination of H3PyImDC and oxalic acid exhibit more diversity coordination modes. On the one hand, the nitrogen atom of the substituent pyridyl group can actively participate in coordination with lanthanide ions, in which the pyridyl group effectively elongated the distance of the organic ligand from 6.0 Å of the H3ImDC to 9.5 Å of the H3PyImDC. Eventually, it can increase the distance between two metal centers and extend the frameworks. On the other hand, as reported in most structures, the oxalic ligand serves as a planar bridging ligand, which can cooperate with H3PyImDC ligand to further stabilizes the frameworks as well.
elements.clean_text: To date, H3PyImDC has presented five types of coordination modes as terminal-, linear-, or T-shaped linkers in the reported structures (see ), while in our structures, H3PyImDC serves as a 4-connected linker with four oxygen and one pyridyl nitrogen atoms participating in coordination with lanthanide ions (). Compared with MOFs constructed by 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid and oxalic acid mixed ligands, the combination of H3PyImDC and oxalic acid exhibit more diversity coordination modes. On the one hand, the nitrogen atom of the substituent pyridyl group can actively participate in coordination with lanthanide ions, in which the pyridyl group effectively elongated the distance of the organic ligand from 6.0 Å of the H3ImDC to 9.5 Å of the H3PyImDC. Eventually, it can increase the distance between two metal centers and extend the frameworks. On the other hand, as reported in most structures, the oxalic ligand serves as a planar bridging ligand, which can cooperate with H3PyImDC ligand to further stabilizes the frameworks as well.

elements.content: The TGA measurements for compounds 1–3 indicated that all the compounds show similar thermal behavior due to their isomorphous structures, and they all exhibit high thermal stability as seen in Figure . Thus, only the thermal stability of compound 1 is discussed in detail. A two-step weight loss was observed in compound 1, an initial weight loss of 7.8% below 160 °C that can be associated to the release of two water molecules (calcd 7.6%). The second weight loss occurred between 160 and 350 °C (8.0%), which is attributed to the removal of Cl– anion (calcd 7.6%). The further weight loss occurred from 350 to 700 °C (48.1%) and is attributed to partial organic ligand decomposition (calcd 47.3%). The final remaining at 700 °C of 34.1% is attributed to the formation of Pr2O3. Similar to compound 1, upon 700 °C heating, the final products of compounds 2 and 3 changed to be Nd2O3 and Sm2O3 powder, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

The TGA measurements for compounds 1-3 indicated that all the compounds show similar thermal behavior due to their isomorphous structures, and they all exhibit high thermal stability as seen in Figure . Thus, only the thermal stability of compound 1 is discussed in detail. A two-step weight loss was observed in compound 1, an initial weight loss of 7.8% below 160 °C that can be associated to the release of two water molecules (calcd 7.6%). The second weight loss occurred between 160 and 350 °C (8.0%), which is attributed to the removal of Cl- anion (calcd 7.6%). The further weight loss occurred from 350 to 700 °C (48.1%) and is attributed to partial organic ligand decomposition (calcd 47.3%). The final remaining at 700 °C of 34.1% is attributed to the formation of Pr2O3. Similar to compound 1, upon 700 °C heating, the final products of compounds 2 and 3 changed to be Nd2O3 and Sm2O3 powder, respectively.

elements.content: TG curves for compounds 1–3 (20–700 °C).

The luminescent properties of three compounds were investigated in solid state at room temperature upon excitation at 300 nm. As shown in Figure , they all show good luminescent properties with narrow, sharp emission bands except for the difference in emission intensities. Compounds 1–3 display intensive blue luminescence emissions at 460, 420, and 436 nm, respectively, which can be attributed to the characteristic transition spectra of H3PyImDC ligand but slightly blue-shifted from the 469 nm emission of the H3PyImDC ligand. The observed blue-shift can be owed to an intraligand π–π* transition, and the enhanced luminescence intensity can be attributed to the strong interactions between the deprotonated HPyImDC2– ligands and the lanthanide centers. The HPyImDC2– and OX2– anions adopts a 4-connected and bridging coordination mode, respectively, in compounds 1–3, which makes HPyImDC2– more rigid and effectively stops the rotation of the pyridyl group, that is to say, it can reduce the vibration-induced deactivation of HPyImDC2– anion. Herein, compounds 1–3 exhibit stronger emission intensities and blue-shift compared to H3PyImDC ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

The luminescent properties of three compounds were investigated in solid state at room temperature upon excitation at 300 nm. As shown in Figure , they all show good luminescent properties with narrow, sharp emission bands except for the difference in emission intensities. Compounds 1-3 display intensive blue luminescence emissions at 460, 420, and 436 nm, respectively, which can be attributed to the characteristic transition spectra of H3PyImDC ligand but slightly blue-shifted from the 469 nm emission of the H3PyImDC ligand. The observed blue-shift can be owed to an intraligand π-π* transition, and the enhanced luminescence intensity can be attributed to the strong interactions between the deprotonated HPyImDC2- ligands and the lanthanide centers. The HPyImDC2- and OX2- anions adopts a 4-connected and bridging coordination mode, respectively, in compounds 1-3, which makes HPyImDC2- more rigid and effectively stops the rotation of the pyridyl group, that is to say, it can reduce the vibration-induced deactivation of HPyImDC2- anion. Herein, compounds 1-3 exhibit stronger emission intensities and blue-shift compared to H3PyImDC ligand.

elements.content: Fluorescent spectra of compounds 1–3 at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 3  Fluorescent spectra of compounds 1-3 at room temperature.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have successfully constructed three isostructural lanthanide organic frameworks with high thermal stability and strong fluorescence properties. Tunable modifications to the H3ImDC ligand with a pyridyl group as a substituted group gave a result to the H3PyImDC ligand in which all the four oxygen and nitrogen atom of pyridyl group coordinate with lanthanide ions so that they prevent the rotatation of the pyridyl group and to expand the frameworks as well. Meanwhile, the H3PyImDC ligand and oxalate ligand cooperate with lanthanide ions to construct three compounds with sqp network. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of MOFs with sqp network based on H3ImDC derivatives and oxalate as a mixed ligand. Obviously, the systematic investigation of the spatial effect of the different substitute groups to the H3ImDC derivatives based framework will be undergoing.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have successfully constructed three isostructural lanthanide organic frameworks with high thermal stability and strong fluorescence properties. Tunable modifications to the H3ImDC ligand with a pyridyl group as a substituted group gave a result to the H3PyImDC ligand in which all the four oxygen and nitrogen atom of pyridyl group coordinate with lanthanide ions so that they prevent the rotatation of the pyridyl group and to expand the frameworks as well. Meanwhile, the H3PyImDC ligand and oxalate ligand cooperate with lanthanide ions to construct three compounds with sqp network. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of MOFs with sqp network based on H3ImDC derivatives and oxalate as a mixed ligand. Obviously, the systematic investigation of the spatial effect of the different substitute groups to the H3ImDC derivatives based framework will be undergoing.

cln_elements.content: A mixture of Ln(NO3)3·6H2O (Ln = Pr, Nd and Sm, 0.5 mmol), H3PyImDC (0.5 mmol), oxalic ligand (0.25 mmol), HCl (0.25 mmol), and 6 mL of H2O was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated at 140 °C for 96 h. Block crystals were collected (50–60% yield based on Ln(NO3)3·6H2O). The phase purity was confirmed by the evident similarities between the simulated and the experimental XRD patterns as seen in . Elemental analysis (wt %) for 1: calcd C 27.04, H 2.06, N 8.60, Pr 28.84; found C 27.22, H 1.98, N 8.64, Pr 28.87. Elemental analysis (wt %) for 2: calcd C 26.86, H 2.05, N 8.54, Nd 29.32; found C 26.96, H 2.02, N 8.62, Nd 29.28. Elemental analysis (wt %) for 3: calcd C 26.53, H 2.02, N 8.44, Sm 30.19; found C 26.52, H 1.95, N 8.64, Nd 30.18. IR (KBr, cm–1) for three compounds as shown in . For 1: 3426 (m), 3146 (m), 1666 (vs), 1528 (vs), 1399 (s), 1126 (w), 790 (vs), 636 (m). For 2: 3426 (m), 3160 (m), 1666 (vs), 1526 (vs), 1391 (s), 1124 (w), 799 (vs), 636 (w). For 3: 3426 (m), 3142 (m), 1660 (vs), 1520 (vs), 1400 (s), 1120 (w), 792 (vs), 630 (w).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Compounds 1-3 

A mixture of Ln(NO3)3⋅6H2O (Ln = Pr, Nd and Sm, 0.5 mmol), H3PyImDC (0.5 mmol), oxalic ligand (0.25 mmol), HCl (0.25 mmol), and 6 mL of H2O was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated at 140 °C for 96 h. Block crystals were collected (50-60% yield based on Ln(NO3)3⋅6H2O). The phase purity was confirmed by the evident similarities between the simulated and the experimental XRD patterns as seen in . Elemental analysis (wt %) for 1: calcd C 27.04, H 2.06, N 8.60, Pr 28.84; found C 27.22, H 1.98, N 8.64, Pr 28.87. Elemental analysis (wt %) for 2: calcd C 26.86, H 2.05, N 8.54, Nd 29.32; found C 26.96, H 2.02, N 8.62, Nd 29.28. Elemental analysis (wt %) for 3: calcd C 26.53, H 2.02, N 8.44, Sm 30.19; found C 26.52, H 1.95, N 8.64, Nd 30.18. IR (KBr, cm-1) for three compounds as shown in . For 1: 3426 (m), 3146 (m), 1666 (vs), 1528 (vs), 1399 (s), 1126 (w), 790 (vs), 636 (m). For 2: 3426 (m), 3160 (m), 1666 (vs), 1526 (vs), 1391 (s), 1124 (w), 799 (vs), 636 (w). For 3: 3426 (m), 3142 (m), 1660 (vs), 1520 (vs), 1400 (s), 1120 (w), 792 (vs), 630 (w).

cln_elements.content:
The TGA measurements for compounds 1–3 indicated that all the compounds show similar thermal behavior due to their isomorphous structures, and they all exhibit high thermal stability as seen in Figure . Thus, only the thermal stability of compound 1 is discussed in detail. A two-step weight loss was observed in compound 1, an initial weight loss of 7.8% below 160 °C that can be associated to the release of two water molecules (calcd 7.6%). The second weight loss occurred between 160 and 350 °C (8.0%), which is attributed to the removal of Cl– anion (calcd 7.6%). The further weight loss occurred from 350 to 700 °C (48.1%) and is attributed to partial organic ligand decomposition (calcd 47.3%). The final remaining at 700 °C of 34.1% is attributed to the formation of Pr2O3. Similar to compound 1, upon 700 °C heating, the final products of compounds 2 and 3 changed to be Nd2O3 and Sm2O3 powder, respectively.

Luminescent Properties

The luminescent properties of three compounds were investigated in solid state at room temperature upon excitation at 300 nm. As shown in Figure , they all show good luminescent properties with narrow, sharp emission bands except for the difference in emission intensities. Compounds 1–3 display intensive blue luminescence emissions at 460, 420, and 436 nm, respectively, which can be attributed to the characteristic transition spectra of H3PyImDC ligand but slightly blue-shifted from the 469 nm emission of the H3PyImDC ligand. The observed blue-shift can be owed to an intraligand π–π* transition, and the enhanced luminescence intensity can be attributed to the strong interactions between the deprotonated HPyImDC2– ligands and the lanthanide centers. The HPyImDC2– and OX2– anions adopts a 4-connected and bridging coordination mode, respectively, in compounds 1–3, which makes HPyImDC2– more rigid and effectively stops the rotation of the pyridyl group, that is to say, it can reduce the vibration-induced deactivation of HPyImDC2– anion. Herein, compounds 1–3 exhibit stronger emission intensities and blue-shift compared to H3PyImDC ligand.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

The TGA measurements for compounds 1-3 indicated that all the compounds show similar thermal behavior due to their isomorphous structures, and they all exhibit high thermal stability as seen in Figure . Thus, only the thermal stability of compound 1 is discussed in detail. A two-step weight loss was observed in compound 1, an initial weight loss of 7.8% below 160 °C that can be associated to the release of two water molecules (calcd 7.6%). The second weight loss occurred between 160 and 350 °C (8.0%), which is attributed to the removal of Cl- anion (calcd 7.6%). The further weight loss occurred from 350 to 700 °C (48.1%) and is attributed to partial organic ligand decomposition (calcd 47.3%). The final remaining at 700 °C of 34.1% is attributed to the formation of Pr2O3. Similar to compound 1, upon 700 °C heating, the final products of compounds 2 and 3 changed to be Nd2O3 and Sm2O3 powder, respectively.

Luminescent Properties

The luminescent properties of three compounds were investigated in solid state at room temperature upon excitation at 300 nm. As shown in Figure , they all show good luminescent properties with narrow, sharp emission bands except for the difference in emission intensities. Compounds 1-3 display intensive blue luminescence emissions at 460, 420, and 436 nm, respectively, which can be attributed to the characteristic transition spectra of H3PyImDC ligand but slightly blue-shifted from the 469 nm emission of the H3PyImDC ligand. The observed blue-shift can be owed to an intraligand π-π* transition, and the enhanced luminescence intensity can be attributed to the strong interactions between the deprotonated HPyImDC2- ligands and the lanthanide centers. The HPyImDC2- and OX2- anions adopts a 4-connected and bridging coordination mode, respectively, in compounds 1-3, which makes HPyImDC2- more rigid and effectively stops the rotation of the pyridyl group, that is to say, it can reduce the vibration-induced deactivation of HPyImDC2- anion. Herein, compounds 1-3 exhibit stronger emission intensities and blue-shift compared to H3PyImDC ligand.

A description of the structure of compounds 1–3. (a) Illustration of the Pr3+ ions, viewed as a 5-connected square-pyramidal building units. (b) Representation of the 3D framework with the elongated channels along [001] direction. (c) Stick view of channels along [010] direction. (d) Polyhedral view of the sqp network. (e) Topological features displayed by (e) tiling style and (f) face symbol for the three-periodic sqp net. Color scheme: carbon = gray, nitrogen = blue, oxygen = red, lanthanide = green.

metadata.title:
Construction of Lanthanide–Organic Frameworks
from 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylate
and Oxalate
